articles.title: About this site
articles.description: Some additional details about the website

articles.title: Assignment 1
articles.contents:
By the night before our next class, please:
Download R and RStudio
Create a project for this class with two folders: class and labs
In your labs folder, create a folder called “lab1”
Download this RMarkdown template and save in that folder
Respond to the questions
Knit RMarkdown to a PDF file and email me
If you have a trouble, no worries, just respond to the same questions in a word document

articles.title: Class
articles.contents:
Distill is a publication format for scientific and technical writing, native to the web.
Learn more about using Distill for R Markdown at https://rstudio.github.io/distill.

              Quantitative Digital Methods | Fall 2022
            
            
              
                
                    
                      
                        Syllabus
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        Tips & Tricks
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        Calendly
                      
                    
                  
                                  
            
          
        
        
        
          
            Welcome!
            The digital world is saturated with data. Websites, social media platforms, and applications track what we do and produce digital traces. These traces have proven useful for social scientists interested in researching online communication and behavior. But, working with this data can be challenging both ethically and technically.
            This class will introduce you to a field that has come to be known as computational social science. In addition to debating the ethics of quantitative digital methods, you will have the opportunity to practice these methods during hands-on lab sessions. You will also learn to code in the R Programming Language, a skill that will serve you well at work and in future research endeavors.
          
        
      
    

    
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Quantitative Digital Methods | Fall 2022

              Welcome!
              The digital world is saturated with data. Websites, social media platforms, and applications track what we do and produce digital traces. These traces have proven useful for social scientists interested in researching online communication and behavior. But, working with this data can be challenging both ethically and technically.
              This class will introduce you to a field that has come to be known as computational social science. In addition to debating the ethics of quantitative digital methods, you will have the opportunity to practice these methods during hands-on lab sessions. You will also learn to code in the R Programming Language, a skill that will serve you well at work and in future research endeavors.

articles.title: Syllabus
articles.contents:
Contents
Schedule
1. Introduction
2. Tidyverse Fundamentals
3. Open Government
4. Text Analysis Fundamentals
5. Social Media Data

Learning Outcomes

Schedule
Prior to each class please read and watch everything listed under discussion. You should have also completed the homework assignment from the week prior by Monday night.
You may wish to also review some of the recommended resources. I would suggest reading these after class, since I will emphasize what is important during my lectures and lab tutorials.
Note that this schedule may change.
1. Introduction
Class 1: Introduction (8/30)
Discussion:
Syllabus
Bail (2020), Installing R and RStudio

Lab: Intro to R and RMarkdown
Homework: Assignment 1
Further resources: Wickham (2016), R Markdown, R Markdown Formats, and R Markdown Workflow
Class 2: Computational Social Science (9/6)
Discussion:
Bail (2020), What is Digital Trace Data? and R Basics
Salganik (2017), Introduction and Observing Behavior

Lab: R Basics
Homework: Assignment 1

Further resources: Grolemund (2014), The Very Basics  Wickham (2016), Data Import and Tibbles,
Class 3: Research Design and Ethics (9/13)
Discussion:
Salganik (2017), Ethics
Salganik, Ethics and Computational Social Science (Part 1, Part 2, and Extensions)

Lab: R Fundamentals
Homework: Download RMarkdown file and follow the instructions

Further resources: Grolemun (2014), Packages and Help Pages and R Objects  Wickham (2016), Strings and Dates and Times
2. Tidyverse Fundamentals
Class 4: Data Visualization (9/20)
Discussion:
Bail (2020), Visualization

Lab: ggplot2

Further resources: Wickham (2016), Data Visualization
Class 5: Data Wrangling (10/11)
Discussion:
Bail (2020), Data Wrangling

Lab: The Tidyverse

Further resources: Wickham (2016), Data Transformation, Exploratory Data Analysis, Tidy Data
Class 6: Functional Programming (10/18)
Discussion:
Bail (2020), Prgramming Basics in R

Lab: Functions

Further resources: Wickham (2016), Pipes, Functions, Vectors, and Iteration
3. Open Government
Week 7: Open Government (10/25)
Open Government I
Lab: Socrata API and Relational Data

Further resources: Wickham (2016), Relational Data
Week 8: Open Government (11/1)
Open Government II
Lab: Spatial Data Analysis

Further resources:
Midterm Assignment: Due 11/7
4. Text Analysis Fundamentals
Week 9: Web Scraping (11/8)
Lab: Web Scraping

Further resources:
Week 10: Preprocessing Text (11/15)
Lab: Preprocessing

Further resources: Silge and Robinson, The tidy text format and Analyzing word and document frequecy
Week 11 (11/22)
Discussion:
Bail, Dictionary-Based Text Analysis

Lab: Dictionary Methods

Further resources: Silge and Robinson, Relationships between words
Week 12 (11/29)
Lab: Topic Models

Further resources: Silge and Robinson, Topic Modeling and Mining NASA Metadata
5. Social Media Data
Week 13 (12/6)
Discussion:
Bail, Text Networks

Lab: Twitter

Further resources: Silge and Robinson, Comparing Twitter archives Bail, Application Programming Interfaces
Week 14 (12/13)
Discussion:
Using images and video data for social science

Lab: Instagram

Further resources:
Final Assignment: Due 12/20
Final Projects:
Open Gov
Web Scraping
Twitter

Learning Outcomes
By the end of this course, you should be able to:
Explain what digital trace data is
Explain what internet protocols are and why they matter
Use the Tidyverse to wrangle and visualize data
Use the R programming language to scrape the web, access APIs, and implement basic text analysis tasks
Formulate quantitative sociological research questions and address them using data and evidence
